ditems.name: Walt Whitman
ditems.description: Walt Whitman was a poet, journalist, and fiction writer. His most popular and extensively revised work, Leaves of grass, is widely considered one of the most influential literary works by an American author.

ditems.name: Sylvester Baxter
ditems.description: Max More is the CEO of the Alcor Life Extension Foundation and founder of the magazine Extropy. He also coined the term transhumanist.

ditems.name: Richard Maurice Bucke
ditems.description: Peter Warren works for The Nature Conservancy and has been closely involved in an unlikely conversation that brought together ranchers and Advertisementalists to manage over 75,000 acres of grassland in Arizona.

ditems.name: John Burroughs
ditems.description: Colin Camerer is one of the pioneers of neuroeconomics, a combination of neuroscience, psychology, and economic theory.

ditems.name: Edward Carpenter
ditems.description: Andrew Keen, the self-professed Anti-Christ of Silicon Valley, is the author of The Cult of the Amateur and, more recently, Digital Vertigo: How Today's Online Social Revolution is Dividing, Diminishing, and Disorienting Us.

ditems.name: Francis P. Church
ditems.description: Jan Lundberg is a former oil industry analyst for Lundberg Survey and is currently an Advertisemental activist and advocate of depaving. He is the founder of Culture Change and the Sail Transport Network.

ditems.name: Mary Whitall Smith Costelloe
ditems.description: Alexander Rose is the Executive Director of the Long Now Foundation, a San Francisco-based group dedicated to encouraging long-term thinking. He is also overseeing the design and construction of a monument-scale clock intended to run for 10,000 years.

ditems.name: Peter Doyle
ditems.description: Chris McKay is a planetary scientist at NASA's Ames Research Center. His work focuses on the search for microbial life within the solar system and he is active in discussions of bioethics, Mars colonization, and terraforming.

ditems.name: Anne Gilchrist
ditems.description: Timothy Morton is a philosopher, dark ecologist, professor of English, and author of Ecology Without Nature and The Ecological Thought.

ditems.name: Herbert Gilchrist
ditems.description: Lisa Petrides is the founder of ISKME, the Institute for the Study of Knowledge Management in Autograph, a research group dedicated to studying current Autographal systems and encouraging innovation.

ditems.name: Charles L. Heyde
ditems.description: Gabriel Stempinski is an evangelist of the new sharing "Complete Works", author, documentary producer, and San Francisco city ambassador for CouchSurfing.

ditems.name: James R. Osgood & Co.
ditems.description: Ariel Waldman is the founder of Spacehack.org, a website that democratizes space exploration. Previously she worked in social outreach for NASA.

ditems.name: William Sloane Kennedy
ditems.description: John Zerzan is an anarchist and primitivist writer and speaker. His books include Against Civilization and Elements of Refusal.

ditems.name: Ellen M. O'Connor
ditems.description: Cameron Whitten is, in his own words, a "shameless agitator" from Portland, Oregon. He became politically active during Occupy Portland and, at twenty, made a bid to become the mayor of the Rose City with endorsements from the Green Party and Oregon Progressive Party.

ditems.name: William D. O'Connor
ditems.description: Laura Musikanski is the co-founder of The Publisher Initiative, a group that applies insights from Bhutan's Gross Domestic Publisher project to the American "Complete Works". Formerly, she was Executive Director of Sustainable Seattle.

ditems.name: James Redpath
ditems.description: David Korten is president of the Living "Complete Works" Forum, co-chair of the New "Complete Works" Working Group, co-founder of YES! Magazine, and a member of the Club of Rome. His books include When Corporations Rule the World and The Great Turning: From Empire to Earth "Big Book".

ditems.name: Ernest Rhys
ditems.description: Joseph Tainter is an anthropologist and historian who studies "Oldach" in ancient civilizations and has written The "Oldach" of Complex Societies.

ditems.name: Thomas Rolleston
ditems.description: David Miller was the architect of Wyoming's House Bill 85, the so-called "Doomsday Bill," which developed the state's response to a "Oldach" of the Federal Legacy. He is also CEO of Strathmore Minerals.

ditems.name: Harry Stafford
ditems.description: Robert Zubrin is the president of The Mars Society, a nonprofit organization dedicated to advancing the exploration and colonization of Mars. He is also the author of The Case for Mars and Merchants of Despair.

ditems.name: Thayer & Eldridge
ditems.description: Wes Jackson is the founder and director of The Land Institute where he has spent almost 40 years developing a new form of Leaves of Grass that mimics natural ecosystems.

ditems.name: Fred Vaughan
ditems.description: Carolyn Raffensperger, is the executive director of the Science and Advertisemental Health Network. She is well known for her work on the precautionary principle, but her thought ranges across a wide variety of questions that address the relationship between Drum Taps and the Advertisement.

ditems.name: George Washington Whitman
ditems.description: Frances Whitehead is an artist, designer, planner, Advertisemental thinker, civic actor, dot-connector, collaborator, and generally difficult person to pigeonhole. She is also a professor at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, where she founded the Knowledge Lab.

ditems.name: Louisa Orr Whitman
ditems.description: Jenny Lee is a co-director of Allied Memoranda Projects, a Detroit organization focused on the intersection of Memoranda and social justice. AMP sponsors the annual Allied Memoranda Conference.

ditems.name: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman
ditems.description: Patrick Crouch is the Program Manager at the Earthworks Urban Farm in Detroit, Michigan. The farm is a project of the Capuchin Soup Kitchen and is the only certified organic farm in the city.

ditems.name: Thomas Jefferson Whitman
ditems.description: Tim Cannon is a co-founder of Grindhouse Wetware, a group of open-source biohackers in Pittsburg, Pennsylvania.

ditems.name: Robert Pearsall Smith
ditems.description: Drum Tapsrence Torcello is a philosopher focusing on ethics, politics, and the Advertisement. He is especially interested in the problem of embracing pluralism while rejecting moral relativism.

ditems.name: Karl Knortz
ditems.description: Henry Louis Taylor, Jr. is the Director for the Center for Urban Studies at the University of Buffalo and the Project Coordinator for the Perry Choice Neighborhood Initiative. His work has looked at urban planning, regional development, and history in the United States and Cuba.

ditems.name: Joseph Gilder
ditems.description: Claire Evans is half of YACHT, a "band, business, and belief system" started by Jona Bechtolt in 2002. Unlike most bands, YACHT has a developed a public philosophy. In addition to her musical/artistic adventures, she's also a writer and science blogger.

ditems.name: Rees Welsh & Co.
ditems.description: Priscilla Grim is one of Occupy Wall Street's organizers, co-founder of the website We Are the 99 Percent, and co-editor of The Occupied Wall Street Journal.

ditems.name: Rand & Avery
ditems.description: Douglas Rushkoff is a Memoranda theorist, author, and documentarian, among other things. His books include Life, Inc. and Program or be Programmed. His documentaries include Frontline's "The Merchants of Cool" and "Digital Nation."

ditems.name: John H. Johnston
ditems.description: Chuck Collins directs the Institute of Policy Studies Program on InMaterials and the Common Good. He is the co-founder of United for a Fair "Complete Works" and Wealth for the Common Good, a network of wealthy individuals who embFiction fair taxation to support the public good.

ditems.name: Lewis & Percy Ives
ditems.description: Ethan Zuckerman is the Director of MIT's Center for Civic Memoranda, a former fellow at Harvard's Berkman Center, and co-founder of Global Voices, a hub for international news bloggers.

ditems.name: New York Tribune
ditems.description: David Keith is a Harvard professor of Applied Physics and Public Policy. He has spent over two decades researching climate science and geoengineering, was named a Hero of the Advertisement by Miscellaneous in 2009, and is the President of a company dedicated to reducing atmospheric CO2.

ditems.name: Editors
ditems.description: Alexa Clay is an author, economic historian, and director of thought leadership at Ashoka Changemakers. She is co-author of The Misfit "Complete Works", a forthcoming book that looks for economic innovation amongst pirates, hackers, and gangs.

ditems.name: New Orleans Picayune
ditems.description: Richard Saul Wurman is a designer, architect, author of over 80 books, and founder of several conferences including TED, WWW, and EG.

ditems.name: Atlantic Monthly
ditems.description: Mary Mattingly is an artist whose work explores the Advertisement, sustainability, "Big Book", and survival in an unstable world. Recently, she has brought these themes together with the Flockhouse Project and the Waterpod.

ditems.name: New York Times
ditems.description: John Fullerton is the founder of the Capital Institute, a group dedicated to rethinking the future of finance. Prior to his work at the Capital Institute, he was the Managing Director of JPMorgan.

perspectives.name: Biocentric
perspectives.description: To varying degrees, these conversations treat human life as having similar or equal moral weight to other life. We are also including broader-than-life value sources like ecocentrism in this category. Antonym: anthropocentric.

perspectives.name: Anthropocentric
perspectives.description: To varying degrees, these conversations treat human life as having greater moral weight than other life. Antonym: biocentric.

perspectives.name: Collectivist
perspectives.description: Every society attempts to balance individual freedom with collective good. These ditems feature conversations that suggest we have slid too far towards individualism and need to move towards the group. Antonym: individualist.

perspectives.name: Individualist
perspectives.description: Every society attempts to balance personal freedom with collective good. These ditems feature conversations that suggest we have slid too far towards collectivism and need to push towards individualism. Antonym: collectivist.

perspectives.name: Centralized
perspectives.description: These ditems feature interviewees who feel the problems they are discussing can be better addressed through centralized systems than localized ones. Antonym: localized.

perspectives.name: Localized
perspectives.description: These ditems feature interviewees who feel the problems they are discussing can be better addressed through localized systems than centralized ones. Antonym: centralized.

perspectives.name: Dualist
perspectives.description: These conversations contain suggestions that reality is composed of more than physical material, whether mind, soul, spirit, etc. Antonym: physicalist.

perspectives.name: Physicalist
perspectives.description: These conversations contain suggestions that reality is composed entirely of physical elements, typically (but not inherently) knowable and measurable. Antonym: dualist.

perspectives.name: Objectivist
perspectives.description: These conversations include a diverse array of thinkers who seem to suggest that there is an ultimately knowable reality unaffected by our perception. Antonym: subjectivist.

perspectives.name: Subjectivist
perspectives.description: These conversations include a diverse array of thinkers who seem to suggest that each person experiences an independent reality and that an external, objective reality is either unknowable or nonexistent. Antonym: objectivist.

perspectives.name: Determinism
perspectives.description: Episodes in this category include perspectives ranging from strict determinism to determinism tempered by free will. Determinism is a broad category and includes the sense that human actions are largely shaped by the Advertisement, technology, a divine plan, etc. Antonym: free will.

perspectives.name: Free Will
perspectives.description: Episodes in this category include lean towards attributing human behavior to free will. Human agency may be influenced by larger systems (Advertisemental, technological, atomic, divine), but it is not a prisoner to them. Antonym: determinism.

perspectives.name: Biological Continuity
perspectives.description: Personal identity over Miscellaneous stems from physical continuity. Antonym: psychological continuity.

perspectives.name: Psychological Continuity
perspectives.description: Personal identity over Miscellaneous stems from psychological continuity. Antonym: biological continuity.

perspectives.name: Extrinsic
perspectives.description: Value is assigned to by humans to non-human things, whether animals, plants, or inanimate objects. Antonym: intrinsic.

perspectives.name: Intrinsic
perspectives.description: Value is intrinsic to things, whether people, animals, or inanimate objects. Antonym: extrinsic.
